So my review will speak to the safety concerns I observed while my two kids were playing at the playground. â  â 1. Lack of netting above equipment. All major overhead areas of an indoor playground need to have fire and rip resistant netting to keep children from climbing over the sides of the equipment and suffering injury and death from a fall. Flyover park has a lack of this netting in any of their equipment that is above ten feet high. This is a direct violation of the ASTM industry standards, the group who licenses indoor playgrounds such as "Flyover Fun Park". Attached photos show the lack of netting where it needs to be. â  â 2. Lack of staffing for a playground of this size. When we were there, I observed four staff. One was in training, and one was behind the concession stand. I would also imagine this is what is causing the lack of cleanliness in the facility. Having this few staff means that the playground can't be correctly supervised and safety issues can't/ won't be addressed. At minimum, there should be six staff with two who are focused exclusively on children's safety. When I asked to speak to a manager, I was told there wasn't one on site. This begs the question, who is in charge? â  â 3. Lack of public water: My kids were thirsty and I asked about a water fountain. I was told they didn't have one, and to buy a bottle of water. I understand this is a business, but profiting off thirsty children who are forced to pay for water seems a horrible way to make money. â  â Seeing the recent negative reviews shows a lack of caring about customers, but I would have hoped Flyover would care about keeping kids safe. The play equipment was clean and there was a nice variety of things to do. There was one person behind the registration counter and another person who worked in the play area trying to engage the kids in play. You do need to supervise your own child to make sure she/he plays safely, which all parents/guardians were doing. There were several slides and several swings, tunnels, small stationery ride on and bouncy toys, and a foam pit. There was also many things to climb onto or under. There was also a small play kitchen area. The bathroom was roomy and clean with a pull down diaper changing station. I do see that the entry way where the cubbies were is a small area but when I went there were only about 6 children (and 6 adults) so this was not an issue. I can see how it would be extremely crowded if it was at full capacity, especially since this is the area where one has to take off shoes and put them back on after the play sessions is over.  I am a pediatric Occupational Therapist and thought the environment was great and safe for kids with special needs however; when I went, there were not a lot of children and adults. At full capacity it might be challenging to children with sensory issues. I will say that I thought it was a fun experience for my grandson. â  â ----------------------- â  â Reviewer: Tania Serpas â Rating: 1/5 â Time: 11 months ago â Review: This is not a place for kids with special needs as advertised. It is more of a place that people take their toddlers and little kids especially during the cold months to enjoy as a playground. Some of the staff are very nice but others leave much to be desired. Did not bother to address the fact that there were two kids running around. My son is autistic and was hyper aware of being singled out in a room full of adults and kids. Another time this same staff member put her hands on my son to "calm him down" and my son slapped her hand away. She proceeded to tell me to do something about it but my response is why are you touching my son when you do not even know what his special needs are and how he will react to being personally touched. Obviously my son read right through her supposed I mean well act and did not like her at all. That was the last time I went there. I do not recommend this place to anyone who has special needs kids especially ADHD, they are not very welcoming.
